text:
I'm giving a talk on julia next week to some colleagues.
I've definitely used multiple dispatch a lot, and I fuzzily I recognise that is very useful and natural, but I'm finding it hard to put into words exactly.
Does anyone have any thoughts that could help please, or any links to people who have articulated this well in the past?
I'm also looking at the connection between multiple dispatch and the specialisation system - I feel like there is some "deep" connection there (the two features seem to work very nicely together) - but again, not sure how to quite articulate it.
Thanks in advance!

elements.text:
I'm giving a talk on julia next week to some colleagues.
I've definitely used multiple dispatch a lot, and I fuzzily I recognise that is very useful and natural, but I'm finding it hard to put into words exactly.
Does anyone have any thoughts that could help please, or any links to people who have articulated this well in the past?
I'm also looking at the connection between multiple dispatch and the specialisation system - I feel like there is some "deep" connection there (the two features seem to work very nicely together) - but again, not sure how to quite articulate it.
Thanks in advance!

text:
Here are links to talks that have helped me by people who probably know what they are talking about :wink::
Multiple dispatch: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kc9HwsxE1OY&ab_channel=TheJuliaProgrammingLanguage>
Subtyping: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y95fAipREHQ&t=1996s&ab_channel=TheJuliaProgrammingLanguage>
The type system in general: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z2LtJUe1q8c&ab_channel=TheJuliaProgrammingLanguage>

elements.text: Here are links to talks that have helped me by people who probably know what they are talking about

text:
Thanks both - will take a look.
I suppose to clarify: I have a solid technical understanding of the mechanics, and I can explain how it all works and happens - the thing I'm struggling to come up with is how to articulate the softer benefits / properties of it all. Basically an answer to the "so what?" question someone comes back with after giving them a technical explanation of multiple dispatch.

elements.text:
Thanks both - will take a look.
I suppose to clarify: I have a solid technical understanding of the mechanics, and I can explain how it all works and happens - the thing I'm struggling to come up with is how to articulate the softer benefits / properties of it all. Basically an answer to the "so what?" question someone comes back with after giving them a technical explanation of multiple dispatch.

text: will the people you're presenting to be from OO backgrounds?

elements.text: will the people you're presenting to be from OO backgrounds?

text: Yes, mostly a mix of statically typed OO languages (java, C++, go) and python

elements.text: Yes, mostly a mix of statically typed OO languages (java, C++, go) and python

text: Then I think one of the best things to show is how multiple dispatch replaces lots of the "design patterns" in OO. The visitor pattern, for example is just solved in julia by defining the right methods

elements.text: Then I think one of the best things to show is how multiple dispatch replaces lots of the "design patterns" in OO. The visitor pattern, for example is just solved in julia by defining the right methods

text: factories are another thing that we just don't need as a result

elements.text: factories are another thing that we just don't need as a result

text: That's a decent idea, thanks. Not sure if I'll have enough time to go into a lot of cases, but perhaps something I can save for the end.

elements.text: That's a decent idea, thanks. Not sure if I'll have enough time to go into a lot of cases, but perhaps something I can save for the end.

text: You could also take a look at this article for inspiration. It uses intuitive examples to illustrate the shortcomings of OO. <https://medium.com/@cscalfani/goodbye-object-oriented-programming-a59cda4c0e53>

attachments.title: Goodbye, Object Oriented Programming
attachments.text: I’ve been programming in Object Oriented languages for decades. The first OO language I used was C++ and then Smalltalk and finally .NET…

elements.text: You could also take a look at this article for inspiration. It uses intuitive examples to illustrate the shortcomings of OO.
